+Kanelsnus
That has more to do with how single letters are pronounced, if written in 
phonetic alphabet, they would look the same.

Unfortunately i don't know the international phonetic alphabet =( so trying 
to explain how the word would be pronounced in an unambigous way would be 
futile, because someone from say... Slovakia, with a similar alphabet, 
would pronounce the word completely different from me (a Norwegian.)

And there is also the fact that with English/American pronounciation, 
people avoid putting certain characters after one another because they make 
the word hard to pronounce when put together. For example, I challenge any 
English speaking person (native) to pronounce "Kvikk Lunsj Kjekssjokolade" 
which is the name of a common brand of chocolate in Norway (it's kind of 
like kit-kat.) To me it's simple because of how i pronounce the word when 
those characters are put together, but it's harder for me to say with an 
English accent, even harder for someone who has no experience with 
Scandinavian language.

+Strazdas today's food is actually less healthier than what it was 200 
years ago in my country.  In New Zealand, the tribal peoples had a 
sustaining and very healthy diet of fern root, sweet potatoes, poultry and 
mostly seafood.  Like most tribal populations, it was infant mortality that 
was the greatest threat but it was not uncommon for these people to live 
past 70s.  And these people were under constant pressure of war.  They were 
seasonal fighters and would fight only in the cold of winter (mostly 
because the other seasons were dedicated to planting crops and fishing).

+Strazdas Where are your sources and data? You can't convince me just by 
claiming the opposite. All convincing sources I have found seem to support 
ages of 70 were not uncommon in the stone age.

In the source I cited, 8 tribes that live in stone age societies today with 
absolutely no reliance on modern science have a modal age of death of 
around 70 (that is, the age with most deaths) if you disregard child 
mortality. In other words, they have more people dying at age 70 than age 
60, 50, 40, etc.
Although naturally deaths between 20 and 70 still outnumber deaths at 70+ 
by a very significant margin. Roughly 2 to 1 or 3 to 1 according to this 
study.

If most stone age cultures today consistently reach 70 years (80+ also by 
no means being unheard of), I can't imagine ages 50 and 60 being so 
exceptional in prehistoric times.

comments.text:
+Eric Signoretti Actually, recent studies suggest that is not true. While 
child mortality was very high with hunter-gatherers (i.e. pre-farming 
societies), mortality rates are drastically lower after about 15 years. 
Many people that survived their childhood used to reach about 60-80 years 
of age in hunter-gatherer societies. And in many tribal cultures today 
about 25-30% of the adults die past the age of 75.

Here's a paper on the subject: 
http://www.anth.ucsb.edu/faculty/gurven/papers/GurvenKaplan2007pdr.pdf
comments.author: Raizin

comments.text:
Because a lot of runners today land on their heels, while our body is 
evolved to land on the forefoot.
If you land on your heel you catch your entire body weight on a stretched 
leg, which I think would explain the knee injuries. Running shoes have a 
lot of padding to make landing on the heel more comfortable (which is 
ironic because most barefoot runners' heels barely support any weight while 
running), but the padding doesn't take away all of the ergonomic problems.
Here's a cool video showing the difference between the running techniques 
of typical runners and barefoot runners, with videos and graphs and stuff: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7jrnj-7YKZE&t=2m18s
comments.author: Raizin

+seblasian Running has been shown to not cause as much damage as originally 
thought, however, most of the damage is done because of: A. shoes - shoes 
prevent you feet from working optimally, and the way you run is completely 
different than running barefoot, this is why barefoot running shoes are 
becoming popular as well a vibram shoes. B. surface - most people these 
days run on concrete/tarmac roads, this can damage the joints. It is even 
worse to run barefoot on roads than with shoes. The solution: Barefoot 
running on soft surface such as sand (the beach) or grass.
comments.author: Eclectic Miasma

comments.text:
As you get older, the number of times you use your joints increases 
overtime. In between your joints us tissue that prevents discomfort as you 
move your joints. Our bodies were never meant to be used to ages seventy or 
eighty, so the tissue at some point will begin wearing away, and lead to 
arthritis. At a younf age running is good, your tissue is fresh and new, 
and you won't have to worry about tissue unless you have a genetic problem. 
But increased physical activity at an old age is not good, because that is 
when it starts to hurt.
comments.author: Murteza Hasan

I guess that depends on what kind of "funny" video you're watching.
Does it involve people getting hurt, and if so in what type of hurt?

getting hurt.
If the video involves something that doesn't hurt someone or something,

You might have a (unconscious) problem with the context of the funny video.

If the seccond part of my story applies, then find out what's troubling you

comments.author: Stephen Mesko

comments.text:
Michael has already talked somewhat about animal communication. Ants use 
pheromones and bees dance, but they can't recombine these to make new words 
(or pieces of information). Birds have different calls that mean different 
things, but still have the same problem. The first time we taught language 
to primates, they found it difficult to pronounce things correctly. Ape and 
monkey mouths are not shaped in a way that allows for the full range of 
human speech. This is also true for babies. Even if a baby magically knew 
how to speak fluent English (or any other language) at birth, their mouths 
are not yet shaped in a way that would allow them to speak correctly.

That leads us to primates and sign language. Attempts to teach sign 
language or written symbols on a giant keyboard have led to the primates 
learning a few hundred words. That's quite highly functional. One team of 
researchers was even able to teach a gorilla that she would someday die. 
This spun her into a bout of depression. *However*, for all the times 
humans have taught language to animals, not once (not ONCE) has any of them 
ever asked a question. The fact that we, as humans, can see others as a way 
to gather information for ourselves and to recognize the agency of others 
is called "Theory of Mind," or ToM. This theory of mind truly sets us apart 
from other animals. Humans are not born with it; you can look up a fun game 
to play with kids that will let you know if they have developed a ToM or 
not. The transition usually happens around the age of 4, or later for 
autistic spectrum individuals. But the fact that our species can develop a 
theory of mind is the biggest cognitive difference that makes humans 
unique. And as always, thanks for reading.

And yes, gravity is the force which stops light from escaping. Said 
gravitational force is given off by the object at the center, due to the 
incredibly large amount of density (as you said). That gravity and all 
gravity, to be exact, has to come from somewhere.
comments.author: John B

comments.text:
+Letanas Volundarkvioa  A black hole has no size. It's a singularity, a 
point with infinite density (afawk). Anyway, it still conserves the total 
amount of mass and therefore total amount of gravitational force. The black 
hole has actually a radius around it where the gravity is so high that not 
even light can scape, but that's generated by gravitational force, it isn't 
the actual matter of the black hole.
comments.author: Hampardo

comments.text:
+SasukeKunDesu Also to build up on this, a "black hole" is not actually a

estimated to be around the size of a softball, but has enough gravitational 
force to even pull in light. Gravity, the force stopping light, is also the 
weakest of the four forces of the universe (Those being: gravity, weak 
nuclear force, electromagnetic force, and strong nuclear force), but is 
still powerful enough to capture the fastest thing in the universe. Kind of

top_comment.text:
Human approximated world record speed: 45km/h
Horse approximated world record speed: 88km/h

Suppose the world records is the average speeds for the species in a race.

Problem: What is the probability that the human would be able to achieve a 
speed of 88km/h over the next x unit of time or unit of distance, given 
that his average speed is 45km/h per x unit of time or unit of distance?

Apply Poisson distribution function:
Probability *=* P(x<=88) - P(x<=87) *=* {[(e^-45)(45^0) / 0!] + 
[(e^-45)(45^1) / 1!] + ... + [(e^-45)(45^87) / 87!] + [(e^-45)(45^88) / 
88!]} - {[(e^-45)(45^0) / 0!] + [(e^-45)(45^1) / 1!] + ... + 
[(e^-45)(45^86) / 86!] + [(e^-45)(45^87) / 87!]} *=* 0.999999995310287 - 
0.999999995310287 *=* 0

By the axioms of statistical mathematics, the probability is *0*, the world 
record human will never be able to achieve the speed that is achieved by 
the world record horse.

The Mongols came from Mongolia to Europe on horse, not on foot.
 ﻿

comments.text:
+Ben Harter
There's no need for the attempted put-down at the end.  If you watched the 
video, you should have noticed that the narrator mentioned nothing about 
sweat glands.  I respect that explanation.  However, I will say that there 
is an obvious level of arrogance that humans have when explaining this 
stuff.  I'll explain via analogy...
Imagine you are the state's best 1500 meter runner.  You are enjoying a 
nice meal in your pajamas at home right before you are about to go to 
sleep.  Unbeknownst to you, just outside your house is one of your track 
competitors, but he has never placed in any meet.  At the moment, he's in 
his running shoes, warmed-up, and ready to compete.  You are are ready to 
go to sleep.  He busts open the door with a knife and starts chasing you.  
You make it outside and start running down the street.  You were completely 
unprepared to run for your life while you're barefoot and in your pajamas.  
He catches you easily, and the consequences are not pretty.
Now, does that mean he's a better runner than you?  No, absolutely not.  
The playing field was not level.  He was prepared to race, you weren't.  By 
analogy, you were like a gazelle who didn't know you had to race until a 
split second before, and your competitor was like a human.
My point is that if a gazelle is prepared and trained to run long-distance 
against a human, I believe the gazelle would win.  The same goes with a 
horse.  They can take water breaks in-between being way ahead during the 
race.  Thus, the statements in the video about humans being better long 
distance runners than a horse and other animals are misleading.
comments.author: Armed Society

comments.text:
+Armed Society Human's can run an animal to death not because we have the 
ability to run faster but because we've developed sweat glands that allow 
us to cool off while other animals, no matter what temperature it is 
outside, simply overheat and become immobile. A mammal almost universally 
has to take one breath per locomotive cycle. This means even at a slow 
gallop a mammal has to breath hard, whereas the normal number of steps per 
breath for humans while staying aerobic is 2-4 steps per breath.
When discussing the Gluteus Maximus's importance in running it is vitally 
important to note that it is not active when walking but only helpful in 
propulsion while running (indeed the Glut also stored fat that was useful 
in long sustained efforts). Other parts of the body including the nuchal 
ligament that stabilizes the head were evolutionary adaptations that only 
make sense in the context of a running man. Plain and simple we all are 
born to run wether you choose an active lifestyle or not.
Fossil evidence suggest our ancestors were very capable of running a little 
more than two million years ago. About the same time the Savannah's were 
emerging and forests where becoming pocketed in the Great Rift Valley. This 
new upright running man, known as the Homo Erectus had a particular 
difference in the size of its brain. To scientist this meant one thing, a 
new supply of food that replaced low calorie roots and bulbs with high 
calorie meat. But weapons such as spears or arrows were not made for 
another 1.8 million years. So how did we get the supply of meet for 1.8 
million years? We used our one advantage against all other animals, our 
endurance.
Also I'd like to add animals can just desire certain traits into existence 
if they are in desperate situation, such as sweat glands to improve their 
ability to cool off. I suggest you re-take bio 101 if you believe that to 
be true.

comments.text:
The nitrogen in the atmosphere scatters the shortest wavelengths (blue 
being part of the visible spectrum for us) first. As the Earth rotates and 
the sun has to go through much longer portions of our atmosphere in order 
to hit our eyes, the longer wavelengths will inevitably be scattered as 
well. Hence the sunset often being red, orange, or yellow.

getting scattered. This is also the reason for the sun to seem yellow, it's 
just white light with the blue part missing.

comments.text:
+Julieta loca
Ok, ok. Think of it this way. Imagine humans as a computer with multiple 
programs (these programs can represent limbs). As other people have said, 
if we had more limbs or muscle in general (i.e., if we were larger), we'd 
need more brains and more hearts to function properly. So for a computer, a 
computer would need more cores, a better processor, etc in order to run 
more programs at once.

Simply put, if we had a huge body, we'd need a much more larger (or 
advanced) heart to pump blood through our entire system, as an example.

comments.text:
We have 2 eyes for depth perception, 2 nostrils because they are designed 
to get clogged to keep out bacteria, 2 ears to identify sound direction, 2 
hands and legs because the body is (relatively) symmetrical and it is much 
more efficient. The brain is actually 2 halves, each of which control half 
of the body, put together. It is just most economical that way. :)
comments.author: Rider32izTru

comments.text:
Our bodies just aren't large or complex enough to need another brain. 
 Something the size of a brontosaur needed a means of controlling it's 
hindquarters since impulses from the brain would take so long to get all 
the way back there.  An Octopus has extremely complicated limbs which 
require extra control.  We have neither of these problems.  Brain tissue is 
useful, but it is also a liability as it requires more calories to sustain. 
 If it doesn't give the creature an edge, it is not useful.  Nature has a 
way of weeding out things that do not prove useful.

comments.text:
+Proxide True, fans don't actually "cool" the air, but imagine the heat 
given off by your body as a sort of cocoon around you - your body gives off 
heat, which heats the air around you, which makes you warmer. Fans simply 
disperse this "cocoon" of heat so that the air surrounding you remains at 
room temperature. The amount of heat given off by the fan's kinetic energy, 
friction etc. is quite small and negligible in a decently-sized room. Same 
thing goes for fans in laptops, cars, etc.
comments.author: UOTCbassist

comments.text:
+Proxide  its actually not that difficult. the moving air creates a FEELING 
of cold. a fan doesn't really cool down things, but moves air, wich in 
itself give you a colder feeling, like when its barely freezing(0°C), its 
frikkin cold when the wind blows, but bareble when out of the wind. next to 
that, when moved hot air rises, making room for cold air, so in the long 
run it gets a little fresher, but never colder . Fans don't ever cool 
things down btw, only heat pumps can do so, by expanding hot air and thus 
subtracting the hot energy from it. how your AC unit works (and gets hot 
actually).

comments.text:
not so much that WE traded but nature traded FOR us.
It's all about survival and passing on genes.
The ancestors we split from likely had sharp teeth and claws since we still 
have sharp canines and fingernails.
However in the distant past as those ancestors (who really could not 
actually be called human) likely would use teeth and claws for defense. 
Then a random mutation occurred and one was born with better stamina and a 
disposition for running like a coward instead of fighting. It lived when 
others would die and cause it lived got to reproduce, a lot. Some of its 
offspring had the same attitude of running away and using its stamina for 
exactly that.
The offspring who fled got to reproduce, a lot. And over time more 
offspring were born who were less equipped to fight, smaller teeth, 
thinner, smaller claws and better stamina as well as a preference to run 
and hide while the ones with sharp teeth and claws and a fighting spirit 
produced different kinds of offspring.

captions.text: Hey, Vsauce. Michael here.
A human, running like a quadruped, is creepy.
Artist Rui Martins created this animation
about a year ago. 127 years ago

Eadweard Muybridge shot these real images
of a child with infantile paralysis
walking on all fours. Walking upright

looks less unnatural, our bodies are
particularly well suited for it. It's one
of the things
the bulbous and prominent

human bottom helps us do.
But let's get to the bottom
of a linguistic mystery. Why is the bottom
called a bottom, when it's in the middle of the body?
Your feet and legs are almost always

at the same level or below your bottom.
I mean, except for
Navasana, the yoga boat pose, your bottom is
anything but the actual bottom of your body.
Unfortunately, there is no clear-cut
answer, but there are butt loads of cool things to learn

about butts. A buttload is not just a
joke amount. It is a very specific

unit of measurement. Historically, it was
used to describe the capacity
of a wine cask. A butt is about
477 litres, which means,
given the average volume of solid waste
the rectum holds, when a person says they have a
buttload of something... Technically,
they are saying they have enough of that thing to fill
3,200 butts. Using the word
bottom to refer to your posterior is relatively new.

Cedric Watts has presented evidence that
in the late 16th century bottom could
connote the human rear end,
but the first published use wasn't until 1794
in Erasmus Darwin's 'Zoonomia'.
The word bottom comes from words meaning

'foundation', 'the lowest level'.
But when standing or sitting,
the soles of your feet are more properly
at the bottom, and, sure enough, sole also means

'foundation', 'bottom'.
What's going on here is probably a combination
of torso-centric thinking and euphemism.
Bottom is a nice word for a sometimes

dirty part and your bottom is the bottom
of your digestive tract and
the bottom of your torso, the bottom of your body,
if you exclude your limbs. For Prince Randian,
a man born in 1871 in British Guiana,
the bottom was the bottom.
Because of tetra-amelia syndrome, he was born with no

limbs at all. In 1889 P.T. Barnum brought him
to the United States to perform

in carnivals. And you can see him
light a cigarette with no arms
or feet in the 1932 film

"Freaks". Bottom is just one of many words
we have for the posterior,
the rear, the backside, derrière, bum,
buns or, in reference to its round shape, moon.
Which is why exposing your bare buttocks
is known as mooning, an offensive gesture.

The earliest known instance of mooning was
recorded by Flavius Josephus. It occurred
in 66 A.D.
A Roman soldier mooned
a group of Jews headed to a temple in Jerusalem.
His act of mooning spawned a riot and the subsequent
overreaction on the part of the Roman military led to the
deaths of thousands of people.
If you get mooned you will,

just like a guy who died September 14th,
1865 and is now buried in West Laurens, New York,

Seymour Butts. At least he didn't
share his name with a former
representative of New Hampshire's
second district. The word 'bum'
predates the use of the word bottom for the rear by quite

a lot. It's believed that the word bum
originated as an onomatopoeia for the
sound of
buttocks slapping against a flat surface.
Seriously. Lazily sitting around on your
bum all day gave American English the word
bum, a loafer, an idle person.
And bum's connotation of uselessness, poor quality
caused it to lend itself in the late 1960s to the word
'bummer', an experience that was worthless -
a letdown. But to be clear, your butt
is a bottom, kind of. It's a bum

but it is not a bummer.
Your butt is magnificent, an example
of what makes the human body so different.

Its shape comes from the
gluteus maximus and gluteus medius muscles as
well as a layer

of fat.
That layer of fat makes the bottom a great cushion
for sitting. Other animals have to sit

by resting weight on their legs
because they lack the nice

bulbous butt of the human. Evolutionary
psychology suggests that our attraction to full
firm bottoms on potential mates was probably
naturally selected. People in the past who liked
big ol' bottoms probably spread their genes quite

well. They probably had a lot of
reproductive success because the calle
pigeon bottom
is a sign of health and youth. A bottom full of shapely fat

is a great energy reserve.
That energy can come in quite handy if
food suddenly become scarce or during pregnancy

or breast feeding. There's a great reddit
thread you can read if you'd like this
evolutionary psychology approach wrapped up in a
Sir Mix-a-Lot's "I like big butts" package.

Because we are bipedal in order to keep
our torsos balanced while moving
we require relatively giant and prominent
muscles in our bottoms, muscles that are so prominent

we have, compared to other apes,
very defined intergluteal clefts.
Butt cracks. This makes
certain hygienic practices more common in humans
than other animals. But those prominent muscles
are worth it. Compared to horses and other quadrupeds
humans can reach impressive long-distance
aerobic endurance running speeds.

This is Katarina Johnson-Thompson,
an Olympic athlete from Great Britain
and an excellent example of the fact that humans
are the running animal.
Hi Michael.
Hi Katarina. Take a look at this.

I'll make it brief, but above and beyond
other animals, humans can:

sweat to efficiently dump body heat,
we have short toes to provide more efficient

force over long periods of running,
our short neck ligaments keep our head perfectly
stable when running,

our uniquely well-developed
Achilles tendon converts elastic energy into
kinetic energy

very well and our tall narrow waists
provide great counter rotation as our legs

swing backwards and forwards.
I like how PZ Myers
sums it up: "Over long distances, the average

speed sustained by a horse is less
than that of the human,

which means that a well-trained
conditioned human being
can keep up with, or even outrun, a horse
if the race is sustained long enough."

For this reason endurance running is
still practiced by a few people on Earth

as a form of hunting and it may have
been vitally important to prehistoric people.

Before domesticated animals and
projectile weapons and traps,
humans caught animals for food in an incredibly

athletic way. David Attenborough
documented this practice fantastically.
You should

definitely watch this clip. An animal
will sprint away from running human
hunters but eventually

have to rest. Humans, on the other hand,
though slow in the short run
can keep going. Like the tortoise, they eventually beat

the hare and can walk right up to the
exhausted and overheated
animal to kill it. We don't have

dangerous claws or massive teeth and
we can pretty much
only outsprint vegetables.
But, in the long run, thanks to things like our impressive
butts, we have superior endurance
when it comes to running. It may be called a bottom

but it's at the top of the list of things
that make the human body amazing.
This video was inspired by Sport Relief.

A great cause that uses sport to raise
money for vulnerable people here in the
UK and abroad.

Check the description of this video to
learn more and watch their interactive
video about how you

can help out and get involved.
But wait a second,

if our bodies are so well developed
for endurance running
how come we don't all run marathons?
How come we don't all enjoy running

or do a lot of it? Well, the thing is all of
this running specialization was
naturally selected
because it helped our prehistoric ancestors survive.

Actually enjoying all of that running was not
naturally selected, it was just a part of their
daily lives. But that doesn't mean that today you can't
get off your butt, use your butt and be proud of it.
The next time someone calls you a butthead say

"thanks, I always knew my head was a
superlative object that set me apart from
the animal kingdom."
Katarina
And as always,
thanks for watching.
